column4: How do you get fried fat drives? Are you talking about the names, corruption, or something else?

dosfsck during boot in edgy/dapper and windows chkdsk can't obviously not agree on what a fat32 filesystem is... so if don't change the default behaviour of fsck'ing the fat drives at boot, dosfsck corrupt the drives
Could it be that fcsk, or dosfsck are checking your drive as fat16, rather than fat32, and could this be caused by an fstab entry where you've marked the drive as fat, rather than vfat?
i don't care /what/ dosfsck does wrong... i just mark all fat-drives as 0 0 in /etc/fstab

My point is that the fstab might be tripping you up, causing the fsck on boot to run with the wrong options, thus "corrupting" your partition, rather than the right thing, so perhaps you should have a look. I'd be surprised if dosfsck is actually doing something wrong.
And looking at the duplicate bugs, the cause is exactly what I suspected, a fat32 partition being treated as fat16.
no, my fstab is alright... dosfsck tripps, by claiming lost clusters and 'repairing' (actually destroying) files... and this is a default behavior.

That sounds wrong to me. I'm not doubting your report, but fat has been around for a looooong time and was from memory the first file system used under linux (I might be mistaken), so the behaviour you're describing just sounds completely wrong.
It *is* completly wrong... but i stopped complaining about edgy bugs a while ago, just finding my silent workarounds
this is a Launchpad bug number, not a bugzilla bugnumber, huh?
hit it on the spot... i too reported a bug some time ago, but this would have been a duplicate
Did you see the comments about the 0 in column 6?
The reason is probably that I always do a /server/-install and then dpkg --set-selections... there might be a different default for server and desktop-installs
I'm going to have a little chat in #ubuntu-bugs about this.
